items.title: validate_webhook Isn't Working
items.body:
I believe `validate_webhook` may be broken:

```
        webhook = pusher.validate_webhook(
            request.headers.get("X-Pusher-Key"), 
            request.headers.get("X-Pusher-Signature"), 
            request.data,
        )
```

This always returns `None` even if I copy and paste the key, signature, and data directly.

It is failing specifically on line `118` in `authentication_client.py`:

```
        if not verify(self.secret, body, signature):
            return None
```

The signature appears to always be different than the one returned by `hmac.compare` in `signature.py`.

items.title: specify urllib3 version requirement in setup.py
items.body:
Hi,
I've seen that requirement.txt has "urllib3==1.24" (as many other libraries, eg. requests) which forbid version 1.25). But setup.py does not contain any version specification for urllib3. 
Can you add the requirement also in setup.py? Otherwise setup.py causes 1.25 to be installed, which conflicts with other libraries which forbid it

thanks

items.title: Collections DeprecationWarning in Python 3.7
items.body:
I know you don't actually claim to support Python 3.7, but just thought I should log that it gives me this warning:

```
site-packages/pusher/pusher_client.py:66: DeprecationWarning: Using or importing the ABCs from 'collections' instead of from 'collections.abc' is deprecated, and in 3.8 it will stop working
```

items.title: notification_client not passing encryption_master_key to super initializer
items.body:
`Client` has a new parameter, encryption_master_key, `NotificationClient` is not updated to pass it around. This causes problems, especially if you pass in a custom `json_encoder`.

```python 
NotificationClient(Client):
 __init__(...)
        super(NotificationClient, self).__init__(
            app_id, key, secret, ssl, host, port, timeout, cluster,
            json_encoder, json_decoder, backend, **backend_options)
```

```python
Client(...)
    def __init__(
            self, app_id, key, secret, ssl=True, host=None, port=None,
            timeout=5, cluster=None, encryption_master_key=None, 
            json_encoder=None, json_decoder=None,
            backend=None, **backend_options):
```

items.title: If tornado backend returns 599 status, we should raise an exception
Allow setting connection_timeout and max_clients options for tornado backend
AsyncIO backend does not process the HTTP response
items.body: The backend imports `process_response` but never uses it. As such, it will never detect any bad HTTP responses.

items.title: Tornado backend does not work with Tornado 5.x
items.body:
> The deprecated alias tornado.concurrent.TracebackFuture has been removed.

https://github.com/tornadoweb/tornado/blob/f6e98e279bf78d2984351062906eb100a7303c35/docs/releases/v5.0.0.rst#tornadoconcurrent

```
from pusher.tornado import TornadoBackend
from tornado.concurrent import TracebackFuture
ImportError: cannot import name 'TracebackFuture'
```

items.title: Getting Data from Bitstamp
items.body:
I hope that you can help me because I'm getting kind of frustrated because of my incompetence;)

I want to get websocket data  from bitstamp to work with it. What I usually did was getting for example price data like ' bitStampTick = requests.get('https://www.bitstamp.net/api/v2/order_book/xrpeur')' and then did my calculations with the data. I put it in a loop so it kind of refreshes the data from time to time.

What I want to do now is receiving that same data (lists or dicts would be great) (even with other pairs) via websocket. I mean its real time data and in this case my code will get more efficient.

My problem is that even if I read through your tutorial I have no idea how to manage that. I'm coding for a wile now but this is my first time with websocket and pusher and I guess that I'm missing some principles about websocket here .

So I would be so glad if you could show me how to do what I want to achieve.

Thanks in advance

Robin

items.title: AsyncIOBackend logs 'unclosed client session' error on each trigger()
items.body:
`pusher==1.7.3` and `aiohttp==2.3.9`

`pusher.trigger` any message, and you'll see the following error if you have logging enabled (this is reported as an error level event to any attached tracing software etc, so it generates a lot of spam):

```
Unclosed client session
client_session: <aiohttp.client.ClientSession object at 0x7f3c9004dba8>
```

items.title: AsyncIOBackend throws error on aiohttp 2.3.9
items.body:
```
'ClientResponse' object has no attribute 'read_and_close'
```

more info: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/34971826/a-python-crawler-not-work-for-asyncio

probable solution: `yield from response.text()` instead of `yield from response.read_and_close()`.

items.title: How to listen to events from channels
items.body:
Apologies if I am not using proper wording but I am mainly comparing wording and architecture of documentation from different Pusher lib projects. 

The case I refer is the use case entitled as "Subscribing to channels" available at [Pusher Java Client # Subscribing to Channels](https://github.com/pusher/pusher-websocket-java#subscribing-to-channels).

I wonder if such use case is also available for programmers using this library project. From reading the read me, the closest thing to Subscription seems to be around the section entitled "Authenticating Channel Subscription". However some points seems unclear IMHO:

* "In order for users to subscribe to a private" — which users? 

* "The client will make a POST request to an endpoint (either "/pusher/auth" or any which you specify) with a body consisting of the channel's name and socket_id." — which client? 

I found quite confusing this specific section and the above points plus also the sample: 

```
auth = pusher.authenticate(

  channel=u"private-channel",

  socket_id=u"1234.12"
)
# return `auth` as a response
```

Which does not indicate what to do with such auth.

items.title: Pusher object creation fails
items.body:
I used pusher library under python versions 2.7.6, 2.7.9 and 2.7.13. While executing following code, it generates following error within python/flask application.

from pusher import Pusher
pusher = Pusher(app_id=app_id, key=key, secret=secret, ssl=True)

>>> ("'pyOpenSSL' module missing required functionality. Try upgrading to v0.14 or newer.",)

After performing following steps, it didn't help.

1. Install pyopenssl 0.14
pip install pyOpenSSL==0.14.

2. Removed ssl=True argument
Pusher(app_id=app_id, key=key, secret=secret)

3. Taking latest version of pusher
pip install -e git+https://github.com/pusher/pusher-http-python.git#egg=pusher

Appreciate any help with above issue.

items.title: notification client does not respect json_encoder settings
items.body: Currently when calling the notify method on a pusher client with custom JSON encoder specified, that `json_encoder` is not used by the underlying `notification_client`, which is pretty inconvenient.

items.title: 'Connection aborted.' errors with python 3.6.1
items.body:
hi guys,
I'm seeing intermittent 'Connection aborted.' errors with python 3.6.1 . the line of code that causes this is 
`
pusher.trigger('private-oms', 'client-message', event)`

> 
ConnectionError: ('Connection aborted.', RemoteDisconnected('Remote end closed connection without response',))

This doesnt happen all the time, but at high rates of call.. it happens pretty frequently. 

Not sure, but possibly related to https://github.com/kennethreitz/requests/issues/3458

any idea of what's happening ?

items.title: Timeouts using Push Notification feature
items.body:
Calling the Pusher notify method **often** (but not always) results in a timeout.

For example doing something like:

> pusher = Pusher(app_id=app_id,
>                 key=key,
>                 secret=secret,
>                 timeout=1,
>                 retry=5, # THE DEFAULT
>                 ssl=False)
> 
> pusher.notify([channel], notification)

Results in:

> requests.exceptions.ReadTimeout: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='nativepush-cluster1.pusher.com', > port=443): Read timed out. (read timeout=1)

Any ideas?

items.title: issue with gevent monkeypatching on python > 3.4
items.body:
from http://www.gevent.org/gevent.monkey.html

> 
> patch_select(aggressive=True)
> Replace select.select() with gevent.select.select() and select.poll() with gevent.select.poll (where available).
> 
> If aggressive is true (the default), also remove other blocking functions from select and (on Python 3.4 and above) selectors:
> 
> select.epoll()
> select.kqueue()
> select.kevent()
> select.devpoll() (Python 3.5+)
> selectors.EpollSelector
> selectors.KqueueSelector
> selectors.DevpollSelector (Python 3.5+)

On python 3.6, if i use gevent monkey-patching ("patch_all"), I start to get following errors on `pusher.trigger('ssssss', 'client-message', event)`

> AttributeError: module 'select' has no attribute 'epoll'

really need help on this

items.title: About semantic versioning and backward compatibility
items.body:
The version 1.6 is not backwards compatible with 1.5. Now, all configuration is hidden inside a `_pusher_client` object. It happened in commit 2e71da394ef5b5d02e933b47aecf35a36de31a27.

For example, I use `pusher.key` in Flask-Pusher package and it failed with 1.6+. I had to make a workaround to fix all my tests and probably you can use the same solution to make it compatible. https://github.com/iurisilvio/Flask-Pusher/commit/4be823fed81b6a37406f5c65386c785329a8f24d

Semantic versioning is important to third-party applications. If you want to break compatibility, change the major version.

items.title: Add support for Python 3 to the setup.py file
items.body: I used caniusepython3 on one of my projects, and it said that pusher is not ready for Python 3, but looks like it is. My guess is that the setup.py file is not up to date.

```
[Wed Jun 22 23:40:24.886791 2016] [wsgi:error] [pid 8753]   File "/home/user1/envs/secure_api/lib/python2.7/site-packages/requests/sessions.py", line 573, in send
[Wed Jun 22 23:40:24.886799 2016] [wsgi:error] [pid 8753]     r = adapter.send(request, **kwargs)
[Wed Jun 22 23:40:24.886805 2016] [wsgi:error] [pid 8753]   File "/home/user1/envs/secure_api/lib/python2.7/site-packages/requests/adapters.py", line 370, in send
[Wed Jun 22 23:40:24.886824 2016] [wsgi:error] [pid 8753]     timeout=timeout
[Wed Jun 22 23:40:24.886830 2016] [wsgi:error] [pid 8753]   File "/home/user1/envs/secure_api/lib/python2.7/site-packages/requests/packages/urllib3/connectionpool.py", line 544, in urlopen
[Wed Jun 22 23:40:24.886840 2016] [wsgi:error] [pid 8753]     body=body, headers=headers)
[Wed Jun 22 23:40:24.886846 2016] [wsgi:error] [pid 8753]   File "/home/user1/envs/secure_api/lib/python2.7/site-packages/requests/packages/urllib3/connectionpool.py", line 344, in _make_request
[Wed Jun 22 23:40:24.886853 2016] [wsgi:error] [pid 8753]     self._raise_timeout(err=e, url=url, timeout_value=conn.timeout)
[Wed Jun 22 23:40:24.886858 2016] [wsgi:error] [pid 8753]   File "/home/user1/envs/secure_api/lib/python2.7/site-packages/requests/packages/urllib3/connectionpool.py", line 314, in _raise_timeout
[Wed Jun 22 23:40:24.886866 2016] [wsgi:error] [pid 8753]     if 'timed out' in str(err) or 'did not complete (read)' in str(err):  # Python 2.6
[Wed Jun 22 23:40:24.886879 2016] [wsgi:error] [pid 8753] TypeError: __str__ returned non-string (type SysCallError)
[Wed Jun 22 23:40:24.887028 2016] [wsgi:error] [pid 8753] [22/Jun/2016 23:40:24] DEBUG [syslog:298] Current Count is: 4
[Wed Jun 22 23:40:24.887176 2016] [wsgi:error] [pid 8753] [22/Jun/2016 23:40:24] DEBUG [syslog:306] Giving up - force: True
```

I am running:
Django 1.8.4, 
python 2.7 
virtualenv. 

The code is executed in a WSGI instance from Apache. 

Pip (8.1.2) Info:
pusher==1.3.0
ndg-httpsclient==0.4.1
pyOpenSSL==16.0.0
six==1.10.0
pyasn1==0.1.9
requests==2.10.0
urllib3==1.16

The source code I am executing is where the exception is thrown and handled by myself:

```
def _check_if_occupied(self, channel_name, count=0):
        """
        Checks if the channel has any occupants, return bool
        :param channel_name:
        :return:
        """
        result = False
        try:
            result = self._check_if_occupied_inner(channel_name, count)
        except Exception:
            pass
        return result
```

```
def _check_if_occupied_inner(self, channel_name, count):
        try:
            channel_info = self.p.channel_info(channel_name)
            logger.debug("Checking for Channel: %s" % channel_info)
            if channel_info['occupied']:
                return True
        except Exception, e:
            logger.debug("Exception occured: %s" % e.message)
            traceback.print_exc()
            count += 1
            logger.debug("Current Count is: %s" % count)
            if 0 < count <= 3:
                self.p = None
                time.sleep(5)
                # create a new pusher instance
                self._create_pusher_instance()
                self._check_if_occupied(channel_name, count)
            if count > 3:
                logger.debug("Giving up - force: True")
                return True
        return False
```

I have a Class Based View in my Django REST API Framework view. This is a an excerpt from a helper class in utils.py. 

`self.p` holds a pusher instance. Before any triggers in other methods I check if actually anyone is in the channel I want to trigger. To do so, I check for the user's presence channel. (Most of the time, but it can also be a private- channel). 

To check I use the `channel_info` method. Unfortunately, I get the traceback that I have posted before. After some investigations it seems like that the host changes in the url coonectionpool and therefore an exception occurs. 

Looking into the pusher debug console on the website shows me that no request was received either. 

To put a cherry on top of this problem: It does not happen regularly, but during various times. I tried spamming it to see if there is some sort of triggerable race condition, but no. It does not matter if I call my method 30 times or 3 times. It can work and then suddenly jump to not working. 

I thought that using a recursive method with a timeout would solve the problem (race condition) - but no. It throws 3 times the exception. 

Then I tried to dispose the self.p instance and create a new one once the exception is thrown. I thought this could deal with some caching issues - but again no luck. 

**Update**:
I tried using other backends, but they seem to fail. GAE seems way to complicated and overloaded for this issue. At least I did not see an easy way to use it. Tornado has "Future" problems. Channel Info doesn't work because instead I get a DummyFuture back which I would then need to process further. 
aiohttp requires python 3.x - not an option at all. 

I have also tried to using a cluster and specified "eu" as in the github docs - which to my luck now shows me the error trace from above ALL the time. Which could lead to the fact that the timeout support does not work correctly ?

items.title: tornado_channel still broken in branch 0.8
items.body:
Hey folks, it seems that the fix that resolves the tornado channel issue isnt reflected when installing version 0.8 via PIP

pip install pusher==0.8
cat /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pusher/init.py

result:

```
class  TornadoChannel(Channel):
    def trigger(self, event, data={}, socket_id=None, callback=None):
        self.callback = callback
        return super(TornadoChannel, self).trigger(event, data, socket_id)

    def send_request(self, signed_path, data_string):
        import tornado.httpclient
        absolute_url = self.get_absolute_path(signed_path)
        request = tornado.httpclient.HTTPRequest(absolute_url, method='POST', body=data_string)
        client = tornado.httpclient.AsyncHTTPClient()
        client.fetch(request, callback=self.callback)
        # Returning 202 to avoid Channel errors. Actual error handling takes place in callback.
        return 202, ""
```

If its compared to what its actually in github, it differs

```
class TornadoChannel(Channel):
    def trigger(self, event, data={}, socket_id=None, callback=None, timeout=socket._GLOBAL_DEFAULT_TIMEOUT):
        self.callback = callback
        return super(TornadoChannel, self).trigger(event, data, socket_id, timeout=timeout)

    def send_request(self, signed_path, data_string, timeout=socket._GLOBAL_DEFAULT_TIMEOUT):
        timeout = None if timeout == socket._GLOBAL_DEFAULT_TIMEOUT else timeout
        import tornado.httpclient
        absolute_url = self.get_absolute_path(signed_path)
        request = tornado.httpclient.HTTPRequest(absolute_url, method='POST', body=data_string, request_timeout=timeout)
        client = tornado.httpclient.AsyncHTTPClient()
        client.fetch(request, callback=self.callback)
        # Returning 202 to avoid Channel errors. Actual error handling takes place in callback.
        return 202, ""
```

As i see, it just needs to be pushed to the PIP repos

items.title: ImportError No module named ndg.httpsclient.ssl_peer_verification
items.body:
After installing pusher into a specific folder with `sudo pip install -t directory pusher`

I try a basic trigger to my app and get this.

> File "deploy/lambda.py", line 5, in 
> pusher = Pusher(app_id=u'**_', key=u''**_", secret=u'***')
> File "/home/vagrant/Code/Lamdba/DevPitch/deploy/pusher/pusher.py", line 42, in init
> from pusher.requests import RequestsBackend
> File "/home/vagrant/Code/Lamdba/DevPitch/deploy/pusher/requests.py", line 12, in 
> import urllib3.contrib.pyopenssl
> File "/home/vagrant/Code/Lamdba/DevPitch/deploy/urllib3/contrib/pyopenssl.py", line 49, in 
> from ndg.httpsclient.ssl_peer_verification import SUBJ_ALT_NAME_SUPPORT
> ImportError: No module named ndg.httpsclient.ssl_peer_verification`

items.title: Shouldn't users_info also return the "user_info" data inside "custom_data" dict?
items.body:
I am trying to retrieve information of the users currently online in a chat room (users subscribed to a pusher channel).

When a user subscribes to the channel the following info is sent to pusher from the Django server:

channel_data

```
{
    'user_id': socket_id,  
    'user_info': {  
        'public_name': profile.public_name,  
        'username': profile.username  
    }  
}  

auth_response = pusher_object.authenticate(  
    channel=chat_channel,  
    socket_id=socket_id,  
    custom_data=channel_data  
)  
```

I was expecting to be able to retrieve this data, also from my Django server. But the only method I see in this library is Pusher::users_info which only seems to fetch the a dictionary containing the user_id of each subscribed user. Is there any way to retrieve also the user_info for each user? whats the reason for including it in the authenticate method if not?

items.title: Django 1.9: ImportError or AttributeError
items.body:
When i do:

```
import pusher
p = pusher.Pusher
```

I get:
`AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'Pusher'`

When i do:

```
from pusher import Pusher
p = Pusher
```

I get:
`ImportError: cannot import name Pusher`

items.title: Channel subscription?
items.body:
Would it be possible to subscribe to channels with this Python library? Especially without having to provide my secret key?

I have a Raspberry Pi where I want to receive Pusher events in a Python program but it seems impossible to do so.

I've been using [this library](https://github.com/ekulyk/PythonPusherClient) but it seems to have some serious problems. For example, the client (apparently) randomly stops calling the event callback when it receives a message from Pusher.

Wouldn't it be possible to have an official Python client library?

Thanks

I know this might not exactly belong here as it is not directly related to pusher, but I thought I let you know that the requirements of pusher cause this issue! I will investigate and post updates for other users...

items.title: OpenSSL on Ubuntu
items.body:
ImportError: python2.7/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/bindings/_openssl.so: undefined symbol: EC_KEY_clear_flags

---

Fixed with:

```
$ pip install pyOpenSSL==0.13.
```

Will investigate further. Either will specify dependency or add note in README. (Don't know enough about this yet)

Ishaan

Hello,

I have used Pusher 1.0.0 on Heroku and it work very well but, when I attempt to upgrade Pusher to 1.2.3. The deploys started failing after that with the following message:

items.title: cacert.py
items.body: As i informed you in person, when i installed the library (not sure if it was from pip or easy_install), i got an error for missing the file "cacert.py", when i copied it from this repository, worked just fine.

items.title: Problem with google app engine
items.body:
I am trying out the latest `master` branch.

First of all, there seems to be a syntax/api issue with  UrlfetchBackend.py

```
--- a/lib/pusher/urlfetch.py
+++ b/lib/pusher/urlfetch.py
@@ -3,7 +3,7 @@
 from __future__ import (print_function, unicode_literals, absolute_import,
                         division)

-import urlfetch
+from google.appengine.api import urlfetch
 from pusher.http import process_response

 class URLFetchBackend(object):
@@ -19,7 +19,7 @@ class URLFetchBackend(object):
       url=request.url,
       headers=request.headers,
       method=request.method,
-      data=request.body,
+      payload=request.body,
       deadline=self.config.timeout,
       **self.options
     )
```

I applied the above patch to get it to run.

Now there is no more runtime exception. Based on my application log I can see I can send message to the pusher server. However my pusher clients (written in javascript) are not receiving any message.

Any suggestion?

 I would also like to know how I can check if I have successfully sent messages to pusher servers, preferably via your some sort of control on pusher website?

items.title: Getting an error from aiohttp.py when installing with pip
items.body:
Python version: 2.7.3

Issued: pip install pusher==1.1.3

Error:

```
Installing collected packages: pusher
  Running setup.py install for pusher
    SyntaxError: ('invalid syntax', ('[REDACTED]/python2.7/site-packages/pusher/aiohttp.py', 24, 29, '        response = yield from asyncio.wait_for(\n'))

```

items.title: JSON encoder is necessary
items.body: The `pusher_client_python` had a configuration to a custom json encoder. This new module does not provide this feature.

items.title: Trigger Multichannel support
items.body:
Has anyone already tackled the problem with missing multichannel trigger support? It's already present in other pusher clients but I think due to the Python clients architecture this is more than a one-liner.. (as opposed to the others)

Your answers are appreciated,
Robert

items.title: GAE urlfetch
items.body: The behaviour of urlfetch will be changed from April 2015. This will need to be taken account of

items.title: Client is no longer working with latest slanger
items.body:
I am getting no more errors about websocket. ping-pong is appearing, however it appears that the python client when using this with slanger (https://github.com/stevegraham/slanger)

https://github.com/pusher/pusher_client_python

does not appear to be sending messages to slanger anymore or the messages are no longer going through. In verbose mode nothing registers when I manually push a message. It comes back without any errors. 

I'm not sure if the new bugfix with slanger is causing this or something else might be happening here.

items.title: UnexpectedReturnStatusError
items.body:
File "./job.py", line 267, in queue_next_job
    p[str(job.id)].trigger('progress', {'status':'Running', 'jobid':str(job.id)})
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pusher/**init**.py", line 78, in trigger
    raise UnexpectedReturnStatusError("Status: %s; Message: %s" % (status, resp_content))
pusher.UnexpectedReturnStatusError: Status: 200; Message: {}

I am using the python client (pip install pusher) and coming across this message. The push happens but it keeps complaining about this issue.

items.title: python 3 support?
items.body: please?

items.title: timeout kwarg needs to be added to extra channels
items.body: Simple change to the code, adding timeout=None to send_request in the TornadoChannel got it up to snuff enough to work fine.

items.title: https?
items.body:
Hi there, any reason why the codebase seems to default and be enforced via assert to http? and not https?

regards
Ross

items.title: Tornado example is broken
items.body:
Getting an error when trying to run the Tornado example:
TypeError: send_request() got an unexpected keyword argument 'timeout'

Only modification was to change the app_id, key, and secret.

items.title: Zero-length channel string is still sent
items.body:
to channels//events
In fact, we blindly stringify channels- is this a good idea? E.g p[None] gets sent as /channels/None/
Also, we don't do anything about slashes included in the string, e.g p["//"] will still be sent.
In my opinion, we should pre-enforce correct urls via regexp

items.title: Null & zero-length app string gets translated into a send to /apps/None/
items.body: Should probably throw an exception before sending, since it cannot be valid

items.title: Channel.trigger no longer returns 202 (now 200 OK)
items.body:
According to the REST API documentation, the Channel.trigger() function should now expect a 200 OK response (rather than the older 202 which has been deprecated).

Are you guys accepting pull requests?

items.title: Mocking __getitem__ on Pusher
items.body:
I'm working on stubbing two parts of the Pusher API so that my unit tests don't actually shove data down the pipe, and so that I can confirm that Pusher is being called with the right data during various operations.

I'm using unittest2 and Mock (http://www.voidspace.org.uk/python/mock/):

``` python
    # spec'd the namespaced version where it's been imported - seems to be a requirement for Mock
    # use MagicMock which also mocks all the magic (__underscored__) methods for the class
    self.mock_pusher = MagicMock(
    spec=myapp.feature.pusher.Pusher,
            autospec=True)
```

As a debug help, I edited `pusher/__init__.py` to let me know when Pusher.__getitem__ has been called.

In my test code:

``` python
    class BasicTestCase(TestCase):
        def setUp(self):
            self.channel_name = 'foo'
            self.mock_pusher = MagicMock(
                    spec=myapp.somemodule.pusher.Pusher,
                    autospec=True)

        def test(self):
            self.do_task_that_gets_a_pusher_channel()
            self.mock_pusher.__getitem__.assert_any_call(
                    self.channel_name)
```

When I run the tests:

```
./manage.py test -v2 myapp.BasicTestCase

test (myapp.tests.BasicTestCase) ... __getitem__: client-foo
FAIL
...
...
======================================================================
FAIL: test (myapp.tests.BasicTestCase)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/steve/PROJECTS/myapp/tests/feature.py", line 257, in test
    self.channel_name)
  File "/Users/steve/envs/myapp/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mock.py", line 820, in assert_called_with
    raise AssertionError('Expected call: %s\nNot called' % (expected,))
AssertionError: Expected call: __getitem__('client-foo')
Not called

```

I've also tried Mocking `pusher.Pusher` instead of the namespaced version, but it doesn't seem to affect the issue.

Thoughts?

items.title: publish 0.6 to pypi
items.body: the latest install instructions will only install the latest version on pypi which is 0.5.

items.title: Support for python 2.4
items.body:
Python 2.4 doesn't have hashlib and its version of hmac aren't compatible with this package. Here's the traceback that is generated:

  File ".../pusher/**init**.py", line 55, in trigger
    status = self.send_request(self.signed_query(event, json_data, socket_id), json_data)
  File ".../pusher/**init**.py", line 68, in signed_query
    signature = hmac.new(self.pusher.secret, string_to_sign, sha_constructor).hexdigest()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.4/hmac.py", line 107, in new
    return HMAC(key, msg, digestmod)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.4/hmac.py", line 42, in **init**
    self.outer = digestmod.new()
AttributeError: 'builtin_function_or_method' object has no attribute 'new'

I'll supply a patch that works in my testing.

items.title: Content-Type header should be set to application/json
items.body:
Without this content-type being set the REST API may not process the request correctly e.g. % characters can cause an empty response to be returned and result in the request not being processed.

Header can be set here: https://github.com/pusher/pusher_client_python/blob/master/pusher/__init__.py#L69
